review_title: What a difference a few years makes….
pros: Great benefits (discounts on products, medical, dental and shares to name a few) and most of the people I worked with are good friends. For managers and above there is also a quarterly bonus if the company hits its revenue targets, which is almost every time because of the volume of sales the company makes. This bonus is never spoken about for some reason, presumably to not alert non-managers who do not get any form of bonus/commission.
cons: Apple Retail used to be the pinnacle of retail, and then Covid came and everything changed. As a tenured manager I saw a lot of changes over the years, some for the good, and some for the bad, but the biggest change has been a complete switching off of the focus on the customer and employee experience. This is mostly driven by senior management who are utterly obsessed with “ownership” (aka sales), AppleCare and business introductions. This constant focus on driving numbers over the customer and employee experience has driven so many people out of the business. It doesn’t matter how much money is made, and how nice the customer feedback for employees was, it was never enough. This was compounded in 2020 when Coaching at Apple was introduced, Apple’s new management program, and managers became “coaches”. This was a fancy title for what most people would call micro-managing, and it meant that talented and empathetic team members were “coached” several times a day to sell AppleCare and get introductions for the business team, even those who didn’t work on the shop floor. This was tiresome for managers, and tiresome for the team, who just wanted to help customers learn about Apple.

review_title: Poor infrastructure, engineering quality and management
pros: Good WLB, not bad pay and stock incentives, and well-rounded processes
cons: Apple is a hardware company, it is not a software company. All decisions can be expected coming from very top down, and the infrastructure is really poor.

pros: Good benefits and acceptable compensation. Long hours, constantly under staffed. Physically and emotionally exhausting but for some reason when you feel appreciated all that can feel energizing.
cons: The difference between a great job that you love and a work environment that you hate is actually quite small. It is usually made up of the people you interact with. One bad local change in leadership can alter culture on a local level quite dramatically. Suddenly you find yourself unappreciated and the herd mentality of ‘yes men’ gaslighting individuals becomes the fulltime job — it becomes your life. Appreciating honesty and values driven decision making, must be central to Leadership. When it is not, you will find highly motivated, effective team members leaving. I guess in a short blurb that is easily digestible, that is the best advice I can offer someone considering to work in the retail environment. It can be a great company to work for, but when it is not — the politics of the organization will crush good people.

pros:
Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) one of the most favorable companies on the market. People like it, traders like it, market likes it. The AAPL stock has one of the highest weighting in the Nasdaq 100, DJI, S&P 500 and Russell 1000 indexes. Many portfolio managers have this stock in their arsenal. Despite the sluggish performance over the past two years, this stock is still have huge base of loyal investors who still believe in the "rising of the fallen star".

Can Apple stock recover from its bad performance and start to shine on the market or Apple's time is over and it will be just an ordinary stock? Below are some cons and pros to consider with respect to the Apple future:
cons:
For the past 5 years the Apple is following the other technology companies. It does not create anything new. It is not a leader in the technology industry any more.
With all due respect, the current company's management does not have a vision for the company's future. With loss of Steve Jobs the company lost it. The company may need new management, new leaders who can look into the future.

review_title: they'll take your soul but at least you'll have healthcare!
pros: healthcare, 401k, stocks, friendly coworkers,
cons:
Oh, you're an artist you say? An actor? A musician? Well, come on down to work at your local Apple Store! The folks at Apple love that you're creative and would like to use your innate, irreplaceable gift to sling iPhones and peddle expensive services no one asked for. They'll rope you in with the amazing healthcare, the 401k, the stock plan, and they'll even sweeten the deal by telling you that you can use your creative talents at work and get paid for it. If you'd like to direct movies then you'll perfect for selling MacBooks because you can talk to people about FinalCut Pro. If you're a musician then surely you know all kinds of stuff about Logic, so go sell more computers, you spineless selling machine! (By the way, did I mention that you will get zero commission for the thousands upon thousands of dollars you bring into this multi-trillion dollar company? That's right, no yucky competition with your fellow plebs, you'll be one big, happy family all working for the common goal of making Tim Cook dirty stinking rich while you slave away for just barely above minimum wage!) 

Then before you know it you've been working for Apple for five years, you've gotten your beloved PLAQUE and you have no idea how you'll survive in the wild because what other entry-level part-time gig will give you $19/hr? What other job can you get that will give you that sweet, sweet full coverage healthcare you've come to enjoy? Not to mention the stocks you'll lose if you quit now, so many of them have yet to vest and if you just wait one more year, two more years, threeeee moooooore yeeeears imagine the kind of money you'll have then!

Oh, and let's not forget about the Career Experiences! Apple will send a few lucky, lucky retail employees to go work up at corporate for six months curating playlists for Apple Music or fiddling alongside nerds with masters degrees on some really cool development job. And the entire time you'll be having a blast, taking pity on your coworkers still stuck at the retails store, while your new corporate managers are constantly dangling the promise of a promotion that will never come to go work permanently in Sunny Cupertino. They'll give you per diem, housing, and more money than you'll know what to do with! But then, your six month career experience will be over and you'll be shipped back to the retail store where you belong, you stinky salesperson. Turns out your theatre degree just wasn't good enough after all, so it's back to wiping boogers off of iPad screens. It's what you we're born to do. 

If you are creative in any way and would like to not be sucked into Apple's ever-churning corporate machine, then you should stay as far away from their stores as possible. Legit, I watched so many amazing and unique people quit their dreams to become a genius admin it makes me sick.

pros: Great job to work at
cons: Low promotion over promised under delivered

pros:
- New ideas are encouraged
- Coworkers and peers are incredibly smart
cons:
- The Apple culture is changing for worse. What was once a prestigious tech company who had a passion for innovation and people has disappeared and turned into a powerhouse of labor exploitation. Expect long hours and little pay
- On average, Apple provides around 3% pay raises each year. This does not cover the increasing costs of living in Austin. It doesn’t matter how great of an employee you are, you should expect 3%. There is no reason to work hard.
- Apple does not care about the city of Austin or the citizens that live here. Apple takes tax breaks and incentives, while continuing to white-wash any culture out of Austin, contribute to awful traffic patterns, and keeping overall city wages stagnant.
- Utilizing time off benefits is frowned upon. Workload sits for you to complete when you return, negating any kind of "refreshment" you feel from being away
- No room for promotions. Management does not care about development or helping you explore other opportunities. 
- Management is constantly talking about how much money our department has saved the company (we’re talking millions of dollars), meanwhile a peer on my team is on food stamps.
- Many of my peers are struggling with mental health issues due to being overworked and not having enough time off. Apple’s health benefits barely cover any type of treatment for mental health issues. Even the “top tier” health insurance plan does not cover widely accepted mental health treatment and instead insurance encourages you to take Xanax.
- When we had on-site doctors, they were low quality and constantly gaslight you

review_title: Marketing/Marcom...It's Gonna Be a No From Me Dawg!
pros: Looks good on your resume, mostly kind and smart peers, learning about new products before the rest of the world, brand new MacBook Pro, team diversity
cons: Where to begin...There are 2345253 people working on 3 projects. Everything is slow, there is no innovation and when you do work on cool projects, they get cancelled at the last minute. Leadership is lacking in Marcom. I had such high hopes of working here but was so let down by the culture and leadership. Marcom leadership doesn't know what they're doing and maybe that's because they don't have to? What makes Apple special is their design and products, not the marketing. Inexperienced leadership was the biggest letdown. I'm sure they are trying their best but it's amateur hour and to top it off they're not very welcoming to new team members. I'm glad I took the job and have it on my resume, but I don't think I would recommend working here in marketing to an enemy.

review_title: Great benefits, work culture and life experience
job_title: Technical Specialist in Belfast, Northern Ireland
pros:
I learned so much working at apple, from interacting with customers, getting opportunities for career experiences over lockdown where we got to see other parts of the company to learning about troubleshooting issues and gaining training on iOS devices (which helped many colleagues when transitioning into other IT-related careers).

The culture at Apple encourages constructive criticism and positive feedback, always with the aspect of positive intent and this gives you so much opportunity to grow in your job.
 
The benefits are incredible, particularly for retail but they’re actually better than what you would even get at most office jobs working for large companies and the benefits even applied equally to part time employees.

You meet some incredible people working in Apple retail, there were some incredibly inspirational colleagues who I got to know and I am still close friends with many of the people I worked with. In all the stores I interacted with there are many opportunities to meet with colleagues outside of working hours, both in and outside of organised work events.

Apple held annual challenges such as “Close your Rings” where you work in teams and can gain exclusive prizes for completing the challenges. These are great for connecting with colleagues, fun to complete and always encourage healthy habits.

The sick policy at Apple is very good, particularly during the pandemic. You don’t usually feel like you will be punished for taking time off for ill health, which is better than other retail companies. You also have a generous allowance of paid sick days. This compliments some of the benefits Apple has like free counselling, Bupa healthcare and free access to mindfulness apps which are usually paid for.
cons:
There is very little opportunity in Apple retail at the minute for promotion. I was in a position where many people at the level above me would have to leave before a position (promotion) would ever be offered for anyone to apply to.

If someone does want to be promoted at Apple the interview process does not appear to always work in the favour of those who are well suited to the role. I knew of people who had worked temporarily in the position they were applying to, had done incredibly well in those positions but failed during the interview process because of how interviews are judged. The process works well against bias but the strict mark scheme can also work against people who have already done well in the role.

If you ever want to cut down your weekly hours there is little opportunity to gain them back again except for temporarily around holidays.

Although feedback is encouraged, even for those of the lowest level roles towards management, if managers or leads were given feedback it often went ignored or was reacted to negatively even if the feedback was clearly given with positive intent. This is a small gripe but it does go against the feedback culture Apple tries to create and I was just lucky that I never had any serious issues with my managers or leads as most of them did not take feedback well.

Organising holidays is pretty bad but not too bad for retail. You usually have to book about a year ahead for any annual leave over the summer months. You have a very generous holiday allowance if you can get them booked fast enough to use them all.

review_title: MY OPINION AFTER ONE YEAR AT APPLE AS A AI/ML ANNOTATION ANALYT
pros:
14 PAYSLIPS
Work from home
Discounts if you like Apple products
cons:
-Incompetents Team Leaders
-The interactions between colleagues doesn't exsist
-NOT ENOUGH Straight to the point explanations for the job
-Useless Apple meetings that least 45 minutes explaining points that makes no sens that can be taken to answer amounts of questions asked by a lot of colleagues about relevants points in the actual job

pros: The discounts are pretty decent.
cons:
Ridiculously low hourly rate for the amount of technical expertise you are expected to have. 

Quite a few managers stand around on the floor not doing much and watch everyone work which contributes to the high pressure environment. The other issue is that customers don’t know these people are managers and so they wonder why they need to wait for help when there are people in an Apple shirt just standing around. 

There are a few managers that hop in and help customers directly. They are always the most supportive and helpful because they understand the pressure. 

Many managers want to constantly tell you how you can improve and “set some goals” rather than actually support you when you need it. When I asked for help I often was told no or received strong push back. Feels like low key emotional abuse.  

All the internal tech systems are complicated and time consuming which makes it stressful to get within the time allocated for an appointment. Especially if you need to run a test multiple times, the algorithm doesn’t care or take it in to consideration. We are basically governed by algorithms that are not human friendly. 

In general Apple talks a lot about “diversity” but take a quick look at their leadership team on the website and you will quickly see how hypocritical they are. They do not walk their talk. 

My mental health has suffered quite badly since working for Apple. I read via the “#AppleToo” stories that if you go to their internal HR department for any type of support that it’s not actually anonymous. Managers find out and then you get managed out of the business.

job_title: Technical Expert in New York, NY
pros: The people you meet are great, everyone is so welcoming, and the team dynamics is the saving grace.
cons: Overworked, understaffed, Change in culture. Queues are being booked at the genius bar for 50 people, with 12 technicans being staffed. A higher focus has been put on selling rather than the technical side of Apple at the store level. My store hired 200 Sales specialist in the last 3 months, while only bringing in 2 new technicians. There has also been a huge change in culture and management, resulting in many seasoned employees leaving for better opportunity & pay. The removal of certifications has also stunted a lot of the external growth an employee can achieve when leaving Apple.

review_title: A retail job that somehow manages to feel like middle school more than anything
pros:
*You get some strong benefits. 

*Generally speaking, I find it easy to have annual leave if booking in advance. 

*The team as a whole are great. Out of all jobs I worked my coworkers are some of the nicest people I've ever met, Apple does a good job at selecting talent. 

*Some of the managers, especially those that started as specialist themselves, are incredible and unbelievably helpful. I've had one of them go so far above what I would've expected of them. 

*There is a good amount of support from leadership if faced with difficult customers. I never get any kind of pushback from the leadership for refusing service to rude/racist customers.

*Apple has been very supportive as a whole throughout the pandemic, it made me feel valued as an employee.
cons:
*As a full timer, there simply is no work life balance. Apple expects you to be available 7 days a week. You won't work more than 38 hours however your schedule will pretty much be utterly random. I realized that as a result, this completely ruined my my social life since I can never plan a single thing with friends. 

*Wage is quite mediocre for the expectations, which offsets the benefits.

*You can't expect to get specific days off without booking far ahead. If you book far ahead, you will rarely get any pushback. HOWEVER, if you ask to get a specific day off in (for example) the upcoming month, they will push back and virtually deny anything unless it's super critical like someone's funeral. As a result, the team call in sick on days they wanted off, leading to a distrustful environment. 

*Speaking of trust, this is my biggest con. Management plays huge favorites, and if you're not on their favorites list you will get treated quite poorly. If you dare call in sick they'll be borderline aggressive and it doesn't even matter if you haven't called in sick for a year. 

*A lot of concerns from the team get utterly disregarded. If a team member has some kind of complaint or anything along those lines they will certainly get pushed back. Sometimes that could also ruin their standing with the leadership. Managers change the topic or refuse to elaborate whenever there is any pushback.

*At Apple, there is a huge conflict of interest between customer service and metrics. You can't have both. Perhaps this works better in the USA but certainly not in Australia. 

*For some reason, some team members get in trouble over virtually nothing, whilst others will not get sacked even if they consistently no-show. As mentioned, managers refuse to elaborate or change the subject. Sometimes they warn you to drop the subject in a borderline threatening tone.

pros: Endless. Love every thing they offer
cons: Non really but the hours can get a little chaotic

pros:
Good benefits as a part timer at the time. Good health+dental insurance, tuition reimbursement. Decent discounts. 
Coworkers were the best part of the job, made some great friends there.
cons:
Three big cons that influenced my eventual exit from Apple: 

1. I was there for 4 years, and during that time the job quickly turned from having genuine human interactions on the sales floor to “would you like fries with that” interactions. It was no longer about listening to customers needs. They wanted us to be rattling off about services customers never mentioned or else our performance scores would go down. Got a 14 year old trying to buy a charging cable? Better mention the business team to him just in case this 14 year old is buying 20 computers a year for his business he might have. It was pretty ridiculous. 

2. Additionally, over time they kept moving product zone specialists to the tech specialist roles, but never hired on more product zone specialists. The job became very stressful as it felt as though there were never enough of us to help all of our customers. It was always very go-go-go, but it got a lot worse with time, as we lost more PZ specialists without replacing them. I remember running from one interaction to the next to try and get through the queue faster. 

3. Management was unchecked. Had managers who stole from the company for a long while before getting caught, others taking fraudulent leaves of absence, others being overtly and covertly racist to employees and/or customers. Took YEARS for a lot of these managers to get caught, because no one took our complaints seriously. The good managers were amazing, but the bad managers made it hard to get by when the good managers weren't scheduled or were on vacation.

pros: Good pay, easy work, great benefits
cons:
Honestly it could just vary on location, but everything seems to be based on the friendships you make. 
Work doesn’t seem to be valued as much as how much you “drink the kool-aid” and kiss butt.

pros:
Amazing health insurance, employee stock purchase program, health and wellness challenges with swag rewards, employee discounts for purchases, fantastic team (mostly, and that varies depending on location). I had some of the best managers I’ve ever had, but it wasn’t within their power to change the issues permeating throughout the business.

I will say Apple didn’t lay off a single person when Covid hit and made sure everyone was paid the average they were getting before the world shut down. I will forever be grateful for that.
cons:
While it is easily the best retail job you can get (with the best pay to match), employees still aren’t paid enough for the amount of work that is required of them. 

Between dealing with extremely angry customers, defending decisions made by corporate that you don’t even remotely agree with, maintaining really high customer service metrics that are affected by those corporate decisions (greyed out speaker on the iPhone 7 Plus should have been covered by a quality program but I’m convinced Apple didn’t want ANOTHER thing to admit after the fiasco that was the “No Service” iPhone 7 problem and the iPhone 6/6S battery issue), an advancement culture that requires you to already “do the work” of the job you’re going for without getting compensated for it, AND an EXTREMELY convoluted interview process to boot. I was “part time” working 30-35 hours per week and had to complete THREE interviews to get full time (40 hours, slightly better benefits) for the same position. Add to that, it’s not what you ACTUALLY do when you’re working, but what you can say you do during the interview process. I watched PLENTY of great candidates get passed up for promotions because someone else who doesn’t contribute is a better talker. 

I spent five years with Apple and I can say that I never want to step foot in there again. The psychological trauma of being regularly yelled at by rude people (a lot of times for issues they caused themselves) overwrote every great interaction I had. 

I was offered that full time position. It felt pretty good to counter that offer with my two weeks notice.
